awd_titl_txt: A Method for Assessing Scour Nuclei in US Inner-to-Mid Continental Shelf
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study submerged prehistoric archaeological sites drowned after the end of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). The sites are expected to be found on the Atlantic Ocean’s Continental Shelf of the Georgia Bight. Such sites are difficult to discover and study but are extremely relevant to understanding human entry adaptations in the Americas. This research seeks to develop a new method of underwater survey designed to overcome many of the costs and difficulties currently associated with underwater archaeological exploration. The study will exploit existing erosional features created around wrecks or artificial reefs. These exposures are compelling targets for archaeological testing because excavation has already been done by natural forces such as tidal currents. A successful study of scour nuclei offers us the ability to advance our understanding of the now drowned paleolandscape of the southeastern coastal plain along the Atlantic. This study will seek to improve current methodologies for survey and recovery of submerged archaeological sites. By so doing, it will broaden the typological and chronological framework for prehistoric sites on the southeastern U.S. continental shelf and it will contribute more broadly to research on drowned paleolandscapes nationally and globally.

This research will examine how natural oceanic forces may reduce effort and costs currently associated with the location and characterization of submerged archaeological sites. Such costs can be significant, and the technology required, while commercially available, does not normally provide an acceptable success rate with regard to prehistoric sites. The researcher will lead a small team of archaeologically and geologically trained students and colleagues. The datasets generated by this team will provide new insights into the feasibility of the methods as well as into the larger picture of the nature and survivability of submerged prehistory in the U.S. offshore. The collaborative focus of the team will provide new and exciting educational opportunities for students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An overall goal of the project was a paleolandscape reconstruction for the inner-to mid-continental shelf of the Georgia Bight. To do this we defined four objectives:

 1. Identify high probability areas for prehistoric human habitation using GIS and extant geological, ecological and archaeological data sets.

2. Perform rapid, first pass assessments of wrecks and artificial reefs within high probability zones using cutting edge sonar instrumentation to identify scour nuclei.

3. Identify scour nuclei locations with high potential for prehistoric archaeological/paleontological remains.

4. The successsful use of geological, paleontological and archaeological materials to develop landscape reconstructions.

Goal #1 was completed by June, 2021.The results guided site investigations conducted from July 2021 to June 2024. Goal #2 was accomplished successfully from fall 2020 to spring 2021.These data were subsequently analyzed using software that extracted important spatial and volumetric parameters about scour and its extent at eight selected study sites

Goal #3. Identification of scour nuclei for study was done by 2021 but their assessment required more time to accomplish than had been intially proposed. There were several reasons for this but offshore weather and sea conditions were the principal factors in scheduling and accomplishing site assessments. June 2022-September 2022 the project was delayed by needed repairs to the research vessel. In 2023 we were able to deploy ocean-scale coring equipment from the oceanographic research ship RV Savannah. This was not originally in our plan but was a welcome addition. April-June 2023 focused on our discovery of a paleo-forest and fossils at Reef SAV, Barge 13. We used both a smaller research vessel and the RV Savannah to characterize the site and recover samples for macrobotanical, microbotanical and paleontological study.

Goal #4 was successfully accomplished by fall 2023 but an extension was requested to conduct further study of the paleosol (ancient soil) at the Barge 13 site in 2024. By integrating these soil data into our overall suite of data, we could reconstruct a paleo-landscape dating to 37,000- 41,000 years ago. It was a landscape in transition from a warmer coastal wetland forest biome to one with cooler-temperate tree species such as spruce, pine and beech. This indicated a colder paleoclimate on the coastal plain. We have integrated these results into previous data taken at locations nearby and developed a more regional view for the the late Pleistocene in the American Southeast. This paleoecology was similar but different from today. The botanical assemblage,while not completely analogous, differed only slightly from that of today. The faunal assemblage was far different. Megafauna and species that survived into the Holocene - horse and bison - roamed these woods and parklands.

We were unsuccessful in locating archaeologically-aged sites or materials among the eight scour nuclei identified and studied from 2021-2024. The Reef SAV site clearly demonstrated the landscape and ecology that early prehistoric colonists would encounter twenty millenia later.

Our most important outcome was the successful demonstration of a methodology using scour nuclei to locate and characterize prehistoric landscapes on continental shelves of the U.S.
